summary.raw:
Cleaned up testing routines for timing and accuracy; migrated transform part to polynomial_MMT class

The dual-transform test (go grid->coeff->grid) has been cleaned up,
generalized and migrated into class polynomial_MMT.  It shows up there
now as a test function and the individual polynomials call it within
their own test routines.  Now you pass it a test function on the grid,
it does two transforms and passes back the result.  The same
dual_transform_test() function works for either matrix-vector or
matrix-matrix transforms.

This eliminates overhead for timing tests, and means that timing tests
and accuracy tests both utilize the same test routine.

passes legendre_transform_test.py tests and one_legendre_transform.py
timing test is giving same results are before.

--Ben Brown, 12/6/13, 10:30am

summary.raw:
PMMT speed SOLVED!  (for matrix-vector at least).

Last major problem was in the memory access pattern for the coeff2grid
transform in `__init__`.  Critical to do:
```
self.coeff2grid_matrix_sym  = np.copy(self.basis_functions[self.i_first_sym:self.N_poly:2, 0:self.N_parity_grid])
```
and not
```
self.coeff2grid_matrix_sym  = self.basis_functions[self.i_first_sym:self.N_poly:2, 0:self.N_parity_grid]
```
First one makes a re-ordered copy of the arrays.  Second one windows
the memory.  Bet we have similar problems with the parity pack and
unpack ops (especially on coeffs).

But now the grid2coeff_pmmt and coeff2grid_pmmt take the same amount
of time, and they're roughly 0.6 (40% faster) than the corresponding
MMT, for matrix-vector test.  About to do matrix-matrix test as well.

--Ben Brown, 12/5/13, 11:10pm

summary.raw:
Shifted PMMTs to broadcast vs. np.tile.  30% speedup or so.

```
python3 -m cProfile -o prof time_legendre_transforms.py
**********************************************************************
    N_grid L_max N_poly |    t_m     t_m/N    t_v      t_v/N  | (t_m/t_v)
PMMT    128    84    82 | 1.11e-04 1.35e-06 3.42e-03 4.18e-05 | 3.23e-02
PMMT    256   169   167 | 5.53e-04 3.31e-06 9.95e-03 5.96e-05 | 5.56e-02
PMMT    512   340   338 | 2.28e-03 6.75e-06 5.19e-02 1.54e-04 | 4.40e-02
MMT     128    84    82 | 9.52e-05 1.16e-06 8.25e-04 1.01e-05 | 1.15e-01
MMT     256   169   167 | 2.91e-04 1.74e-06 6.03e-03 3.61e-05 | 4.82e-02
MMT     512   340   338 | 1.94e-03 5.73e-06 9.75e-02 2.88e-04 | 1.99e-02
Basic timing tests for PMMT and MMT, with Matrix-Matrix (t_m), then Matrix-vector (t_v) transform
**********************************************************************
```

Funny... the matrix-vector PMMTs are showing the right kind of 2x
speedup compared to the matrix-vector MMTs, but the matrix-matrix PMMT
is falling flat.

--Ben Brown, 12/5/13, 9:25pm

summary.raw:
Time-testing; stripped timing test to essentials, shifted to broadcast vs. tile.

Using Numpy broadcast rules to build the weights*basis_func transform
array appears to be much better than doing an explicit
np.tile(weights) transformation to a 2-D array and then explicit 2-d
array multiplication.  Nice suggestion Keaton!  For at least one
profiled test, this makes a factor of 2 difference in the grid2coeff
transform timing (but the times in those is behaving very
sporadically, sometimes short sometimes long).

Time to try this in the PMMTs too.

--Ben Brown, 12/5/13, 9pm

summary.raw:
Made stripped down "speed_test" versions of matrix transform tests, for timing

The argmax() commands and other tests for correctness of the
transforms were really slowing down the speed (they were ~50% of the
cost sometimes!), throwing off our timing results.

These were discovered after visiting with Keaton, when he introduced
me to basics of Python timing and profiling (Thanks Keaton!!!).
```
python3 -m cProfile -o prof time_legendre_transforms.py
```

See next commit too.

--Ben Brown, 12/5/13, 4:55pm

summary.raw:
Reordered test output, shrank legendre_transform_PMMT_test.py driver to make clearer.

Test output now gives:

      m, L_in, L_power_max_out, ||a||_1, ||g_in-g_out||_2

where g_in are the input grid values, g_out is the forward-reverse
transformed grid values, ||a||_1 is the sum of all coeff powers and
L_power_max_out is the peak coeff after forward transform.

Expect:

     L_in = L_power_max_put
     ||a||_1 = 1
     ||g_in-g_out||_2 = machine precision

Added all of this to the transform_on_blank_test() docstrings.

--Ben Brown, 12/3/13, 2:20pm

summary.raw:
Cleaned up tests & transforms.  Added forward() and reverse() method, with self.use_parity flag.

Added a forward (to coeff) and reverse (to grid) transform method the
the Legendre_MMT object.  These test whether self.use_parity is True,
and if yes they call the PMMT's and if no they call the MMTs.

This hides the fiddly details of the transform calls and permits tests
that are agnostic the MMT vs PMMT, which cleans up the test suite.

--Ben Brown, 12/3/13, 2pm

summary.raw:
Fixed PMMT matrix-matrix transform.  Passes all tests.

Critical that the append statement in grid2coeff do the append on
axis=0.  Otherwise, both grid_values_sym and grid_values_asym are
flattened before the append operation.  When we forget this, this
takes our nice 2-D matrix of simultaneous transforms and turns it into
an unintelligible 1-D array.  Fixed.

Looks like PMMTs and MMTs work for both vectors and matrices.

Going to clean up tests, etc., and add forward and backward
operations, plus a use_parity flag in the Legendre_MMT object.

--Ben Brown, 12/3/13, 1:20pm

summary.raw:
Found other 1-D vs 2-D assumption in PMMT; also removed cruft, updated assumptions.

We no longer assume N_poly is even in the PMMTs.

The coeff unpack (de-interleave) operation in coeff2grid_PMMT needs to
know if we're 1-D (transforming a single vector) or 2-D (transforming
a matrix of simultaneous vectors).  Added.

Matrix-Matrix PMMTs are still untested, but I'm about to fix that.

summary.raw:
Fixed L_min != m problems.  Passes tests.  Cleaned up some outputs.

The problem lay in the P_lm recursion.  This needs to start at L=m,
even when L_min>m.  For now we compute the full recursion, then window
down on return.

Also cleaned up some of the verbosity on the outputs.  Setting
verbose=True will still probably overwhelm you with output, but now
the transforms are substantially quieter.

--Ben Brown, 12/3/13, noon:25pm

summary.raw:
Got parity issue sorted!  PMMTs work.

Finally remembered that for P_{lm}s, the l=m mode is completely
concentrated at the equator.  Thus l=m modes have even parity.  So the
right thing to do is test mod(l_min, m)==1.  If true, then odd parity,
if false then even parity.  This leads to even L having even parity
when m is even and odd l having even parity when m is odd.  Explains
all of my earlier confusion :)

PMMTs pass all current tests.

--Ben Brown, 11/24/13, 9:15pm

summary.raw:
PMMT for grid2coeff_PMMT transform added.  Works.

The two PMMTs work coupled with each other.  Awesome.

Tested for m=0 case.  Still probably not robust for N_poly not even.
Need to address this for Legendre transforms, as different m's will
have different N_polys for fixed L_max.  Think this is straightforward
to do (only the coeff_sym and coeff_asym will ever be different
lengths).

Also, the grid2coeff_PMMT transform has 2 explicitly coded sections
that depend on the dimensionallity of the grid values (here assumed
to be 1-D, so single transform).  This comes up in the parity unpack
(in the data trim part) and in the coeff interleave step at the end.

We'll address them later; that's enough for tonight.
--Ben Brown, 11/23/13, 1:15am

summary.raw:
Enabled matrix-matrix transforms; added test.  Moved transform tests into routines.

Added the transform tests to the transform object; generalized the MMT
to handle matrix-matrix transforms.  This was very straightforward in
python compared to Fortran, where we had multiple overloaded
routines.  Here a single routine handles coeff2grid for either vector
(single transform) or matrix (multiple transform) inputs.  Likewise
for grid2coeff.

Tested for m=0 to m=4 on L_max=6 and N_grid=60.

--Ben Brown, 11/22/13, 9:20am

Legendre_roots: added compute_Pn to compute legendre polynomials; added plots; continue_tests flag.

Added method to compute all legendre polynomials P_n for n=[0,N] by
recurrence, as well as the first and second derivative of these P_n
(also via recurrence).  These are un-normalized and grow with N.

Added plots to show the first N_max (currently 6) Legendre
polynomials, computed on a collocation roots grid.

Added "continue_test" flag to check whether to continue on to
"huge_grids" and the sparse solve comparison.

summary.raw:
Now with BDF (but only to order 3).

BDF shows regions of _instability_ (stability is domain outside of the
filled contours).  Higher order BDF methods become increasingly
unstable.  I stopped at order 3, because the instability region
quickly wraps into the solution domain (left hand side of zero).

note to self:
     doing IMEX stabilitiy boundaries is the subject of homeworks
5.12 and 5.13 in chapter 5 of Ascher & Petzold.

Guess I see what my homework is :)

--Ben Brown, 11/1/13, 11:15pm

summary.raw:
Adding stability boundary plot routine for fully explicit AB methods.

This is based off chapter 5 of the textbook by Ascher & Petzold.

For fully explicit AB methods, this successfully reproduces the
boundariers shown in figure 5.5a (and similar plots in Canuto et al,
Vol 1 or 2, Appendix D, figure D1).

This is explicit only, and doing the same thing for imex timesteppers
will take some thinking, but neat to see how nicely we can draw the
boundary itself (previously I had brute-forced this by doing a
point-by-point computation of the polynomial growth amplitude).

--Ben Brown, 11/1/13, 10:55pm

summary.raw:
Added Bessel function in a disk (radial geometry) test.  Not yet working (or correctly coded).

This is the start to a bessel function in a disk test.  This does not
yet work: in particular, the coeffs for the higher order matrices are
certainly wrong (need affine transformation coeffs).  Think of the
current matrices as conceptual placeholders for the 0-term, linear
term, and quadratic term in z (call them L1_0, L1_1 and L1_2
respectively for the L1 matrix).  The real matrices should be something
like this:

     L1[0] = A_00 L1_0 + A_01 L1_1 + A_02
     L1[1] = A_10 L1_0 + A_11 L1_1 + A_12
     L1[2] = A_20 L1_0 + A_21 L1_1 + A_22
     L1[3] = A_30 L1_0 + A_31 L1_1 + A_32 (?)
       ...

Where A_ij is the affine transformation coefficient taking the z^j
term to the correct i order dedalus matrix.  So for now, in the code
I've defined L1_{0,1,2} (though I've done so as L1[0], L1[1], L1[2]).

--Ben Brown, 10/11/13, noon:30

summary.raw:
Notes started on implementing isothermal gwave problems in a disk geometry.

The geometric factor in annular/disk/spherical geometries gives an
interesting test of non-constant coefficients in Dedalus.  For a
special isothermal atmosphere, we know the exact form of the
eigenfunctions for different subsonic equation sets.  In contrast to
the plane parallel atmosphere case, these various eigenfunctions
differ substantially in radial geometries.

--Ben Brown, 10/10/13, 1:15pm

summary.raw:
Significant update to gwave_notes

Now include non-dimensionalzation based on entropy drop, brunt
timescale, density scale height, and background density.

This is now done for Fully Compressible Euler (FC) equations, for
linear Generalized Pseudo-Incompressible (PI) equations, and for
energy-conserving anelastic LBR equations.

Notes are included for pseudo-energy conserving Maestro LM equations,
as well as pseudo-energy conserving anelastic ANS equations
(the old ASH equations).

Boundary conditions are laid out for the adiabatic case.
--Ben Brown, 10/9/13, 1:30pm
